title:
A convergent scheme for the Bayesian filtering problem based on the
  Fokker--Planck equation and deep splitting

sections.text:
#### Abstract

A numerical scheme for approximating the nonlinear filtering density is introduced and its convergence rate is established, theoretically under a parabolic Hörmander condition, and empirically in two numerical examples. For the prediction step, between the noisy and partial measurements at discrete times, the scheme approximates the Fokker-Planck equation with a deep splitting scheme, combined with an exact update through Bayes' formula. This results in a classical prediction-update filtering algorithm that operates online for new observation sequences post-training. The algorithm employs a sampling-based Feynman-Kac approach, designed to mitigate the curse of dimensionality. The convergence proof relies on stochastic integration by parts from the Malliavin calculus. As a corollary we obtain the convergence rate for the approximation of the Fokker-Planck equation alone, disconnected from the filtering problem.

## 1. Introduction

Approximate nonlinear filters often rely on assumptions of unimodality (e.g., Kalman filters [31]) or computationally cheap tractable simulations. The latter mainly refers to sequential Monte Carlo methods, also known as particle filters. Despite their effectiveness in various settings and their asymptotic convergence to the true filter, these methods suffer from the curse of dimensionality with respect to the state dimension $[42,44,48,49]$. There is currently a lot of progress within the Bayesian filtering community, e.g., [39], where sampling-based methods have improved substantially $[12,13,22,40,50,53]$. However, the curse of dimensionality remains an open problem for the nonlinear case.

One motivation for developing methods suitable for a high-dimensional setting comes from applications. There exist numerous domains of applications for Bayesian filtering: target tracking $[7,15,26]$, finance $[17,52]$, chemical engineering [45], and weather forecasts [9, 19, 24], to mention a few prominent ones. Many problems are inherently high-dimensional. An extreme example is [2], in which the authors discuss the challenge in weather forecasting with a corresponding dimension of $10^{7}$ that arises from the spatial domain.

To address the challenge of high-dimensional applications, effective methods for Bayesian filtering must be developed to manage the complexity of the state space and accurately estimate the filtering probability distribution. In many settings, it is desirable to obtain the probability density of the filter and not only estimates of mean and covariance, or a finite number of particles. We refer to the filtering probability distribution as the probability of observing a hidden state $S_{k}$ given noisy measurements $y_{0: k}$ up to time $k$. If such a density $p_{k}$ exists, it satisfies, for a measurable set $C$ in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$, the relation

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(S_{k} \in C \mid y_{0: k}\right)=\int_{C} p_{k}\left(x \mid y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} x
$$

Moreover, it can be shown that this density adheres to an evolution equation: for discrete observations, it satisfies a Fokker-Planck equation [34], and for continuous observations, it satisfies the Kushner-Stratonovich equation [36]. There are approximation techniques that work well in low dimensions to obtain the filtering density through solving these (Stochastic) Partial Differential Equations (PDEs). These classical techniques, such as finite elements [8] and finite differences, are

real-time efficient only in one dimension and stop to be computationally feasible in state dimension $d \geq 4$, which is insufficient for most applications.

In recent years with the explosion of machine learning in applied mathematics, there has been a lot of work going towards efficient deep learning solutions to PDEs. Direct approaches such as PhysicsInformed Neural Networks (PINN) [43], deep Backward Stochastic Differential Equation (BSDE) methods [1, 20], deep neural operators [38], deep Ritz method [21], deep Picard iterations [29], and more, have shown excellent performance in handling higher dimensions to different degrees. Recently, there was success with a score-based PINN applied to a high-dimensional Fokker-Planck equation in [30]. However, in general, there are challenges with these methods with respect to modeling probability densities. Specifically, because the Fokker-Planck equation models a probability density function associated with Brownian motion and, since in very high dimensions, its values become extremely small, this poses challenges for existing methods in terms of numerical accuracy.

In this paper, we focus on further development of one such approximation technique, called Deep Splitting. It was demonstrated to perform very well for PDEs with strong symmetries in dimensions up to 10000 [5], and has been extended to partial integro-differential equations [23]. For the Zakai equation [51], different deep splitting methods have been applied for offline filtering, when the solution is approximated for a single observation sequence $[4,14,37]$. In a subsequent work, deep splitting was combined with an energy-based approach on the Zakai equation and generalized to the online setting where it showed promising results for a state dimension up to $d=20$ [3]. Here we extend it to a format more interesting for most applications in engineering and science, namely the setting where the underlying process $S$ is continuous in time and space, but the observations $O$ are discrete in time. This is done by propagating the Fokker-Planck equation for the prediction and by updating the solution with Bayes' formula at every measurement.
1.1. Problem formulation. Let $B$ be a Brownian motion on some complete probability space, $T>0$ denote a terminal time for the filtering, and $0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{K}=T$ be observation times. The filtering problem in question deals with time-continuous state and time-discrete observations, where the state and observation models are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{d} S_{t}=\mu\left(S_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\sigma\left(S_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} B_{t}, \quad t \in(0, T] \\
& S_{0} \sim q_{0} \\
& O_{k} \sim g\left(O_{k} \mid S_{t_{k}}\right), \quad k=0, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

In this setting we refer to the $\mathbb{R}^{d}$-valued process $S$, solving a Stochastic Differential Equation (SDE) with drift $\mu$ and diffusion coefficient $\sigma$, as the unknown state process and the $\mathbb{R}^{d^{d}}$-valued variable $O=\left(O_{k}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$ as the observation process. We stress that (2) is a statistical model, only used in a distributional sense, meaning that pathwise values of $S$ and $O$ are irrelevant and therefore notation for the probability space is not introduced. In any sensible statistical procedure, the distribution of $O$, determined by the model (2) is approximately that of the data $y$, as otherwise the filter will output nonsense. The model implicitly defines a measurement likelihood $L\left(y_{k}, x\right):=p\left(O_{k}=\right.$ $\left.y_{k} \mid S_{t_{k}}=x\right)=g\left(y_{k} \mid x\right)$, and in Section 2.2 we establish rigorous regularity conditions for the measurement likelihood $L(y, x)$. The standard measurement model, used in almost all publications on filtering with discrete observations, is the Gaussian model with $g\left(y_{k} \mid x\right)=N\left(y_{k} ; h(x), Q\right)$, where $h$ is a measurement function and $Q$ is a covariance matrix. The filtering problem, i.e., the problem of obtaining the filtering density (1), assuming the state and observation model (2), and given data $y$, can be solved by recursively solving a Fokker-Planck equation and by updating using Bayes' formula. To formalize the unnormalized exact filter we initialize $p_{0}\left(0, x, y_{0}\right)=q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right)$, and recursively define

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{k}\left(t, x, y_{0: k}\right)=p_{k}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k}\right)+\int_{t_{k}}^{t} A^{*} p_{k}\left(s, x, y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} s, \quad t \in\left(t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right], k=0, \ldots, K-1 \\
& p_{k}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k}\right)=p_{k-1}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

Throughout this paper the filter, $p_{k}$, is denoted with three arguments $(t, x, y)$, rather than the conventional $(t, x \mid y)$. This should not be confused with the joint distribution over $(t, x, y)$, which we do not address here. The distribution is unnormalized, since the normalizing factor in

the Bayes formula has been neglected, but is otherwise a classical Bayesian filtering system of recursive prediction-update steps. The operator $A^{*}$, that appears in the Fokker-Planck equation in (3), is the adjoint of the infinitesimal generator of the diffusion process $S$ in (2). It remains to solve (3) to define $\left(p_{k}\right)_{k=0}^{K-1}$ including a final update at time $t_{K}$ to define $p_{K}$. In Section 2 we introduce a Feynman-Kac based solution $\widetilde{\pi}$, that approximates the exact filtering density $p$. It is defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n+1}(x, y)\right)_{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right)} \\
& =\underset{u \in L^{\infty}\left(\operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) ; C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}{\arg \min } \mathbb{E}\left[\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}, Y_{0: k}\right)-G \widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right)\right|^{2}\right] \\
& k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0, \ldots, N-1 \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{0,0}\left(x, y_{0}\right)=q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{k, 0}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)=\widetilde{\pi}_{k-1, N}\left(x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $Z$ is an Euler-Maruyama approximation of $S$, or rather of the solution $X$ of an SDE with the same distribution as $S$ but driven by a Brownian motion $W$ on a probability space $(\Omega, A, \mathbb{P})$. The operator $G$ is a first order differential operator. By solving the optimization problem and finding $\widetilde{\pi}_{k}$ for all $k=0, \ldots, K$, one has obtained a machine for approximating the unnormalized filtering density (and prediction density) for all possible measurement sequences $y \in \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) \subset$ $\mathbb{Y}:=\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(K+1)}$ with probability distribution $\mathbb{P}_{Y}$. This makes inference for the online setting very efficient.

The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of this new scheme and its corresponding error analysis. We derive a strong convergence rate in $L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)$ of order 1 in time, assuming a parabolic Hörmander condition as in [10]. The convergence rate is independent of the distribution of the data $y$. The analysis relies in part on stochastic integration by parts from the Malliavin calculus. See Appendix A for an exposition of this theory.

This paper is organized as follows: In Section 2 we present the setting and notation that we use and derive the approximations. In this section we also show regularity and uniqueness of the solution to (3), and of its approximations, and state the main theorem on strong convergence. Section 3 contains the proof of the strong convergence and some auxiliary lemmas that we need. Finally, in Section 4 we detail the additional approximation steps needed for a tractable method based on neural networks and examine the convergence order numerically. Appendix A contains a brief presentation of relevant parts of the Malliavin calculus.

# 2. The online deep splitting filter and main results 

In this section, we present the notation, the background, and formal derivation of the method.
2.1. Notation. We denote by $\langle x, y\rangle$ and $\|z\|$ the inner product and norm in the Euclidean space $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ if $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and the Frobenius norm if $z \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$. The space of functions in $[0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, which are $k$ times continuously differentiable in the first variable and $n$ times continuously differentiable in the second variable with no cross derivatives between the variables, is denoted $C^{k, n}\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. Furthermore, functions in the space $C_{b}^{k, n}\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ have bounded derivatives. The space $C_{b}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ consists of functions in $C^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ which, together with their derivatives, are of most polynomial growth. Similarly, functions in the space $C_{0}^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right) \subset C^{k}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ are such that they and their derivatives tend to 0 at infinity. For $n$ or $k=\infty$, we adopt the usual modifications. Let $(A, \mathcal{B}, \nu)$ be a measure space and $U$ be a Banach space. By $\mathcal{L}^{0}(A ; U)$, we denote the space of strongly measurable functions $f: A \rightarrow U$ and by $L^{0}(A ; U)$ the equivalence classes of functions in $\mathcal{L}^{0}(A ; U)$ that are equal $\nu$-almost everywhere. The Bochner spaces $L^{p}(A ; U) \subset L^{0}(A ; U), p \in[1, \infty]$, are defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|f\|_{L^{p}(A ; U)} & :=\left(\int_{A}\|f(x)\|_{U}^{p} \mathrm{~d} \nu(x)\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}<\infty, \quad p \in[1, \infty) \\
\|f\|_{L^{\infty}(A ; U)} & :=\sup _{x \in A}\|f(x)\|_{U}<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

Here and throughout the paper, we write sup to mean the essential supremum. For Banach spaces $U$ and $V$, we denote by $\mathcal{L}(U ; V)$ the space of bounded linear operators that map from $U$ to $V$.

For smooth vector fields $V, W \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ we define the Lie bracket of $V$ and $W$ by

$$
[V, W](x)=D V(x) W(x)-D W(x) V(x), \quad x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

Here $D V(x)$ is the Jacobi matrix of $V$ with respect to $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. We say that vector fields $V_{0}, \ldots, V_{n} \in$ $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ satisfy a parabolic Hörmander condition if, for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{span}\left\{V_{j_{1}}(x),\left[V_{j_{1}}(x), V_{j_{2}}(x)\right],\left[\left[V_{j_{1}}(x), V_{j_{2}}(x)\right], V_{j_{3}}(x)\right], \ldots ;\right. \\
j_{i} \in\{1, \ldots, n\} \text { for all } i=1, \ldots, n\}=\mathbb{R}^{d}
\end{gathered}
$$

To improve clarity, we suppress $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ in equations throughout the paper whenever appropriate. We define the index set $\mathcal{I}_{K, N}:=\{0, \ldots, K-1\} \times\{0, \ldots, N\} \cup\{K\} \times\{0\}$, for $K, N \in \mathbb{Z}_{+}$. Finally, if $R$ is a stochastic process, then we let $R^{t, x}$ denote the conditioned process $R$ that starts in $x$ at time $t$, so that $R_{t}^{t, x}=x$.
2.2. Setting. Throughout the rest of Sections 2 and 3 we assume that the following holds. Let $T>0$, and $d, d^{\prime}, K \geq 1$ be positive integers. We consider $K+1$ uniformly distributed observation times, denoted $\left(t_{k}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$, satisfying

$$
0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{K-1}<t_{K}=T
$$

with $t_{k+1}-t_{k}=\frac{T}{K}$ for $k=0, \ldots, K-1$. Moreover, for numerical approximations we use a family of finer uniform grids given by

$$
t_{k}=t_{k, 0}<t_{k, 1}<\cdots<t_{k, N-1}<t_{k, N}=t_{k+1}, \quad k=0, \ldots, K-1
$$

with $t_{k, n+1}-t_{k, n}=\frac{T}{K N}$ for $k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0, \ldots, N-1$. In our error analysis, we write $\tau:=\frac{T}{K N}$.
The underlying state process $\left(S_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ is $\mathbb{R}^{d}$-valued and, for convenience, we define $\mathbb{Y}:=\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(K+1)}$ to denote the space of data measurements. We denote by $y_{k: n}, 0 \leq k \leq n$, the $d^{\prime} \times(n-k+1)$-matrix $\left(y_{k}, y_{k+1}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)$.
Throughout the paper, we use a filtered probability space $\left(\Omega, \mathcal{A},\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}, \mathbb{P}\right)$ equipped with a Brownian motion $W$ adapted to $\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$.
The assumptions on the functions in the statistical model (2) are listed next.
(i) The coefficients $\mu$ and $\sigma$, initial density $q_{0}$, and measurement likelihood $L$ are bounded, infinitely smooth and with bounded derivatives, i.e., $\mu \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right), \sigma \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}\right)$, $q_{0} \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right), L \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}} \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$.
(ii) The coefficients $\mu$ and $\sigma=\left[\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{d}\right]$, where $\sigma_{i}$ denotes the $i^{\prime}$ th column of $\sigma$, satisfy the parabolic Hörmander condition, i.e., the vector fields $V_{0}, \ldots, V_{d}$ defined by

$$
V_{i}=\sigma_{i}, \quad \text { for } i=1, \ldots, d, \quad V_{0}=\mu+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{d} D V_{j} V_{j}
$$

satisfy (4) for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$.
2.3. Solution to the filtering problem and deep splitting approximations. The filtering method considered in this paper is a version of the method in $[3,4]$ but now adapted to the case of discrete observations. More precisely, we model the state, denoted $S$, with an SDE and the observation process, denoted $O$, with discrete random variables coupled to discrete time points of $S$, see (2). Under the conditions of Section 2.2, it is well known from the literature that the SDE in (2) has a unique solution $S$. That the observation process $O$ is well defined is clear. We remind the reader that the problem under consideration is that of finding the conditional probability distribution of $S_{t}$ given the measurements $y_{0: k}$, up to and including time $t$. More precisely, we are

for $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ interested in the unnormalized conditional density $p\left(t, x \mid y_{0: k}\right), t \in\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right)$, satisfying for all measurable sets $C$ in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ the relation

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(S_{t} \in C \mid y_{0: k}\right)=\frac{\int_{C} p\left(t, x \mid y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} x}{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} p\left(t, x \mid y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} x}
$$

To this end, we introduce the Fokker-Planck equation. We recall that the state process $S$ satisfying (2) has an associated infinitesimal generator $A$. This operator and its formal adjoint $A^{*}$, are defined, with $a:=\sigma \sigma^{\top}$, for $\varphi \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, as

$$
A \varphi=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{d} a_{i j} \frac{\partial^{2} \varphi}{\partial x_{i} \partial x_{j}}+\sum_{i=1}^{d} \mu_{i} \frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial x_{i}} \quad \text { and } \quad A^{*} \varphi=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{d} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x_{i} \partial x_{j}}\left(a_{i j} \varphi\right)-\sum_{i=1}^{d} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{i}}\left(\mu_{i} \varphi\right)
$$

To connect with the framework of the deep splitting method $[3,4,5]$, we write $A^{*}=A+F$, where the first order differential operator $F$ is defined by, for $\varphi \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right), x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$,

$$
(F \varphi)(x)=\sum_{i, j=1}^{d} \frac{\partial a_{i j}(x)}{\partial x_{i}} \frac{\partial \varphi(x)}{\partial x_{j}}+\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{d} \frac{\partial^{2} a_{i j}(x)}{\partial x_{i} \partial x_{j}} \varphi(x)-\sum_{i=1}^{d} \frac{\partial \mu_{i}(x)}{\partial x_{i}} \varphi(x)-2 \sum_{i=1}^{d} \mu_{i}(x) \frac{\partial \varphi(x)}{\partial x_{i}}
$$

The recursion (3), that defines $\left(p_{k}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$, then becomes

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p_{k}\left(t, x, y_{0: k}\right)=p_{k}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k}\right)+\int_{t_{k}}^{t} A p_{k}\left(s, x, y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{t_{k}}^{t} F p_{k}\left(s, x, y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} s, \quad t \in\left(t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right] \\
& k=0, \ldots, K-1 \\
& p_{0}\left(0, x, y_{0}\right)=q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
& p_{k}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k}\right)=p_{k-1}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

The solution $\left(p_{k}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$, obtained by solving (5) for every path $y_{0: K} \in \mathbb{Y}$, involves both prediction, when $t \in\left(t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right]$, and filtering, when $t=t_{k}$. The following proposition summarizes the regularity of the solution.

Proposition 2.1. There exists a unique $p_{k} \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; C\left(\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right), k=0, \ldots, K$, satisfying (5). Moreover, $p_{k}(y) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{1, \infty}\left(\left[t_{k}, t_{k+1}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ ) for all $k=0, \ldots, K, y \in \mathbb{Y}$.

Proof. We fix $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ and begin by noting that if $p_{k-1}\left(t_{k}, y_{0: k-1}\right) \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, then $p_{k}\left(t_{k}, y_{0: k}\right)=$ $p_{k-1}\left(t_{k}, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, since $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ is an algebra. In particular, this holds for $p_{0}\left(0, y_{0}\right)=q_{0} L\left(y_{0}\right)$. It remains to prove that the Fokker-Planck equation is regularity preserving and that $p_{k}$ is continuously differentiable in time. For this purpose it is enough to consider one step and to prove that $p_{0}\left(y_{0}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{1, \infty}\left(\left[0, t_{1}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. The conditions of $[10$, Theorem 4.3$]$ are satisfied under (i) and (ii) of Section 2.2, which tells us that the probability density of $S$ is infinitely smooth and bounded. More precisely, for all $t \in\left[0, t_{1}\right]$ we have $p_{0}\left(t, y_{0}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. It remains to show the time regularity. In [16, Chapter 9] the semigroup $(P(t))_{t \geq 0}$ of bounded linear operators on $C_{\mathrm{b}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ is defined as the solution operator to the Kolmogorov backward equation. Likewise, one can define the adjoint semigroup $R=P^{*}$ on $C_{\mathrm{b}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, associated with the forward equation (5). From this we have for $t \in\left[0, t_{1}\right]$ that $p_{0}\left(t, y_{0}\right)=R(t) \phi_{0}$, where $\phi_{0}:=p_{0}\left(0, y_{0}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. Following [16, Proposition 9.9] one can analogously show that for all $\psi \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ it holds $A^{*} R(t) \psi=R(t) A^{*} \psi$. In particular, this holds for $\psi=\phi_{0}$ and therefore

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} p_{0}\left(t, y_{0}\right)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} R(t) \phi_{0}=A^{*} R(t) \phi_{0}=R(t) A^{*} \phi_{0}, \quad t \in\left[0, t_{1}\right]
$$

From the regularity of $\phi_{0}$ we have that $A^{*} \phi_{0} \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ and thus $\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t} p_{0}\left(t, y_{0}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ for all $t \in\left[0, t_{1}\right]$. This shows that $p_{0}\left(y_{0}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{1, \infty}\left(\left[0, t_{1}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. Lastly, the uniqueness of $p_{0}\left(y_{0}\right)$ follows analogously to [16, Theorem 9.11] and uniqueness of $p_{0} \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; C\left(\left[0, t_{1}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d}, \mathbb{R}\right)\right.$ follows since $L$ is uniformly bounded and thus so is $\phi_{0}=L(y) q_{0}$ over $\mathbb{Y}$.

Remark 2.1. The solution to (5) gives unnormalized densities. Instead, in $[11,18]$ the normalized update step is used, replacing the third row of (5) with

$$
p_{k}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k}\right)=\frac{p_{k-1}\left(t_{k}, x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right)}{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} p_{k-1}\left(t_{k}, z, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, z\right) \mathrm{d} z}
$$

The benefit of directly obtaining a normalized density has to be compared to the additional computational cost of evaluating or approximating this integral. In this work, we consider the unnormalized version.

The scene is now set for applying the deep splitting methodology between each of the measurement updates. However, the derivation in this paper is done in a slightly different way that avoids the explicit splitting equations seen in $[3,5]$. This leads to the same approximation scheme in the end, but is beneficial for our error analysis. To prepare for Feynman-Kac representations, used in the the deep splitting scheme and the error analysis, we introduce $X:[0, T] \times \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d}$, that for all $t \in[0, T], \mathbb{P}$-a.s., satisfies

$$
X_{t}=X_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} \mu\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} \sigma\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}, \quad X_{0} \sim \widehat{q}_{0}
$$

Here $\widehat{q}_{0}$ is a probability density with finite moments. A natural choice is $\widehat{q}_{0}=q_{0}$, but to emphasize that this is not necessary, and since it gives increased flexibility in the resulting optimization problem, we have a general $\widehat{q}_{0}$ here. From this point, with a slight abuse of notation, we let $t_{n}:=t_{0, n}, n=0, \ldots, N$, and the previously defined time points $\left(t_{k}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$ will consistently be denoted by $\left(t_{k, 0}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$. We have the following Feynman-Kac representation for the solution $p_{k}$.

Proposition 2.2 (Feynman-Kac representation formula). The solutions $p_{k}, k=0, \ldots, K-1$, to (5), in the time points $t_{k, n+1}, n=0, \ldots, N-1$, and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, x, y_{0: k}\right)= & \mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}, y_{0: k}\right)\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}, y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. The proof follows a standard derivation; see, e.g., [32]. We start by fixing $y \in \mathbb{Y}$. Furthermore, we simplify the notation by omitting the dependence on $y_{0: k}$, where it is possible to do so without confusion. We start by noting that the solution $p_{k}$ to (5), for $n=0, \ldots, N-1$ and $t \in\left(t_{k, n}, t_{k, n+1}\right]$, satisfies

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} p_{k}(t)=A p_{k}(t)+F p_{k}(t)
$$

Reparametrization of time $t \mapsto t_{k, N}-t$, so that $t_{k, N}-t \in\left(t_{k, n}, t_{k, n+1}\right]$, yields

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t\right)+A p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t\right)=-F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t\right), \quad t \in\left[t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}, t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}\right)
$$

Noting that $X$ has the same generator $A$ as $S$, and the fact that $p_{k} \in C^{1,2}\left(\left[t_{k, 0}, t_{k+1,0}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, allows us to use Itô's formula for $p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t, X_{t}\right)$. This gives, $\mathbb{P}$-a.s.,

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t, X_{t}\right)= & p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right)+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t}\left\langle\nabla p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right), \sigma\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}\right\rangle \\
& \left.+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial s} p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right)+A p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Inserting (8) into the third term we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t, X_{t}\right)= & p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right)+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t}\left\langle\nabla p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right), \sigma\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}\right\rangle \\
& -\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

We recall that $p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, y_{0: k}\right) \in C_{6}^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ for all $s \in\left[t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}, t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}\right)$ and that $\sigma$ is bounded. This guarantees that

$$
\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\sigma\left(X_{s}\right)^{\top} \nabla p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} s<\infty
$$

and hence the Itô integral in (9) is a square integrable martingale with respect to $\mathcal{F}_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}$. Taking the conditional expectation in (9) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t, X_{t}\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right] \\
& \quad=\mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right)-\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

By reordering the terms and using the fact that $p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right)$ is $\mathcal{F}_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}$-measurable, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right)= & \mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t, X_{t}\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

We note that the right endpoint limit in $t \in\left[t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}, t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}\right)$ satisfies

$$
p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t\right) \rightarrow p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right) \quad \text { as } \quad t \rightarrow\left(t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}\right)
$$

and $\mathbb{P}$-a.s.

$$
X_{t} \rightarrow X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}} \quad \text { as } \quad t \rightarrow\left(t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}\right)
$$

Combining these we see that the $L^{2}$-limit of the right hand side of (10) satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{t \rightarrow\left(t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}\right)} \mathbb{E} & {\left[\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-t, X_{t}\right)+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right.\right.} \\
& \left.\left.-\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}}\right)+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)\right]^{2}\right]=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Inserting the limit from (11) in (10) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right)= & \mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}}\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Rewriting the conditional expectation with respect to a conditioned process $\left(X_{t}^{s, x}\right)_{t \geq s}$ (starting in $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ at time $s$ ), and making the $y_{0: k}$-dependence explicit in the notation, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}, x, y_{0: k}\right)= & \mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, X_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}}^{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}, x}, y_{0: k}\right)\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}}^{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s, X_{s}^{t_{k, N}-t_{k, n+1}, x}, y_{0: k}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we note that $t_{k, N}-t_{k, n}=t_{N}-t_{n}$ for all $k$ and $n$. The proved identity holds for all $y \in \mathbb{Y}$. This completes the proof.

In the next step, we consider a forward Euler approximation of the integral term in (7). First, we introduce the first order differential operator $G$ acting on $\phi \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ according to

$$
(G \phi)(x)=\phi(x)+\tau(F \phi)(x), \quad x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

We define the approximations $\pi_{k, n+1},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$, at each time step $t_{k, n+1}$, of (7) by the recursive formula

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{k, n+1}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)= & \mathbb{E}\left[G \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}, y_{0: k}\right)\right] \\
& x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, y \in \mathbb{Y}, k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0, \ldots, N-1
\end{aligned}
$$

satisfying

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{0,0}\left(x, y_{0}\right) & =q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
\pi_{k, 0}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right) & =\pi_{k-1, N}\left(x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that we have $n=0$ in the final update for $k=K$. Thus, $\pi_{k, n}$ is defined for $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}=$ $\{0, \ldots, K-1\} \times\{0, \ldots, N\} \cup\{K\} \times\{0\}$.

Proposition 2.3. There exists a unique $\pi_{k, n} \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right),(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, satisfying (13) and (14). Furthermore, $\pi_{k, n}(y) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ for $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}, y \in \mathbb{Y}$.

Proof. We fix $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ and suppress it from the notation whenever suitable. The lemma is proved by induction. For the base case, with $k=0$ and $n=0$, from the assumption (i) of Section 2.2 we have $\pi_{0,0}\left(y_{0}\right)=q_{0} L\left(y_{0}\right) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. For the induction step we take $k \in\{0,1, \ldots, K\}, n \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$, and assume that $\pi_{k, n-1} \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. We use the fact that $\pi_{k, n}(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[G \pi_{k, n-1}\left(X_{t_{y}-t_{n-1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n-2}}\right)\right]$, is the Feynman-Kac solution $u:\left[t_{k, n-1}, t_{k, n}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, at the left endpoint $t_{k, n-1}$, to the Kolmogorov backward equation

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(t, x)+A u(t, x)=0, \quad t \in\left[t_{k, n-1}, t_{k, n}\right) ; \quad u\left(t_{k, n}, x\right)=\left(G \pi_{k, n-1}\right)(x)
$$

As a consequence of the assumption, we have $G \pi_{k, n-1} \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ since $\mu$ and $\sigma$ are infinitely smooth. By [34, Theorem 4.8.6] or [28], $u(t) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ for all $t \in\left[t_{k, n-1}, t_{k, n}\right]$ and this shows that $\pi_{k, n} \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. For the case $n=1$ we stress that, by the definition of $\pi$, we take $\pi_{k, 0}=\pi_{k-1, N} L$ and notice that it belongs to $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. The uniqueness of the solution follows by [16, Theorem 9.11]. From the boundedness of $L$ it follows that $\pi_{k, n} \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)$ and this completes the proof.

The convergence of this approximation is stated in the following lemma, which we prove in Section 3.3 .

Lemma 2.1. Let $p_{k}, k=0, \ldots, K$, be the solution to (5) and $\pi_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (13) and (14). For $\tau:=\frac{T}{K N} \leq 1$, there exists $C:=C(T, \mu, \sigma, L, K)>0$, such that

$$
\sup _{(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}}\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \leq C \tau
$$

Since the equation for the process $X$ lacks analytical solution in general, we must consider approximations. On the finer time mesh $t_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$, we define an Euler-Maruyama approximation $Z$, with $Z_{0,0} \sim \widehat{q}_{0}$, by

$$
Z_{k, n+1}=Z_{k, n}+\mu\left(Z_{k, n}\right)\left(t_{k, n+1}-t_{k, n}\right)+\sigma\left(Z_{k, n}\right)\left(W_{t_{k, n+1}}-W_{t_{k, n}}\right)
$$

For convenience, we let $Z_{n}:=Z_{0, n}, n=0, \ldots, N$. Now, we define the approximations $\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}$, of $\pi_{k, n+1}$, by replacing $X$ with $Z$ in (13), i.e., by the recursion

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)= & \mathbb{E}\left[G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}^{t_{n+1}, x}, y_{0: k}\right)\right] \\
& x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, y \in \mathbb{Y}, k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0, \ldots, N-1
\end{aligned}
$$

satisfying

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bar{\pi}_{0,0}\left(x, y_{0}\right) & =q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
\bar{\pi}_{k, 0}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right) & =\bar{\pi}_{k-1, N}\left(x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

The following proposition can be proved identically to Proposition 2.3, adapting arguments with $Z$ satisfying an SDE with piecewise constant coefficients on each time interval $\left[t_{k, n}, t_{k, n+1}\right)$.

Proposition 2.4. There exists a unique $\bar{\pi}_{k, n} \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right),(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, satisfying (16) and (17). Moreover, $\bar{\pi}_{k, n}(y) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ for $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}, y \in \mathbb{Y}$.

The following lemma states the convergence of this second approximation step, with the proof being addressed in Section 3.3.

Lemma 2.2. Let $\pi_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (13) and (14), and $\bar{\pi}_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (16) and (17). For $\tau:=\frac{T}{K N} \leq 1$, there exists $C:=C(T, \mu, \sigma, L, K)>0$, such that

$$
\sup _{(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}}\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \leq C \tau
$$

Finally, we reach our first main result, namely the convergence of the approximation $\bar{\pi}$ of $p$.
Theorem 2.1. Let $p_{k}, k=0, \ldots, K$, be the solution to (5) and $\bar{\pi}_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (16) and (17). For $\tau:=\frac{T}{K N} \leq 1$, there exists $C:=C(T, \mu, \sigma, L, K)>0$, such that

$$
\sup _{(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}}\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \leq C \tau
$$

Proof. This follows directly from Lemmas 2.1 and 2.2 together with the triangle inequality.
2.4. Optimization based formulation of the deep splitting scheme. Here we reformulate the conditional expectation, formulated as a conditioned process in the proof of Proposition 2.2, as the optimum from a recursive minimization problem. This will allow us to approximate the solution by means of a neural network and stochastic gradient descent. We discuss this approximation further in Section 4.2, in the context of numerical examples. The first optimization problem defined below gives a solution to the recursion (16) for a fixed $y \in \mathbb{Y}$, and was first introduced in [4] for stochastic PDE trajectories. In [14] a similar approach was introduced for the FokkerPlanck equation. A scheme based on this formulation requires retraining of the neural network for every observation path and works in an offline setting, where one is only interested in the inference of a single path. We prove this proposition below and an alternative proof can be found in [6, Proposition 2.7].

Proposition 2.5. The functions $\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}, k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0, \ldots, N-1$, defined in (16) and (17) satisfy the minimization problems

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)\right)_{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \\
& \quad=\underset{u \in C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}{\arg \min } \mathbb{E}\left[\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}\right)-G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, y_{0: k}\right)\right|^{2}\right], \quad n=0, \ldots, N-1, y \in \mathbb{Y}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. We start by fixing $y \in \mathbb{Y}, k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0, \ldots, N-1$, and introduce the random variables

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi_{k, n+1} & =\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}, y_{0: k}\right) \\
\Xi_{k, n} & =G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, y_{0: k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By (16) we have $\Phi_{k, n+1}=\mathbb{E}\left[\Xi_{k, n} \mid \mathfrak{S}\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}\right)\right]$. and by the interpretation of the conditional expectation as an orthogonal $L^{2}$-projection, see [33, Corollary 8.17], we thus have that $\Phi_{k, n+1}$ is the unique minimizer in $L^{2}\left(\Omega ; \mathfrak{S}\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}\right)\right)$ of $\Phi \mapsto \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\Phi-\Xi_{k, n}\right|^{2}\right]$. Moreover, we have $\Phi_{k, n+1}=$ $u^{*}\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}\right)$, where

$$
u^{*}=\underset{u \in \mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{b}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}{\arg \min } \mathbb{E}\left[\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}\right)-\Xi_{k, n}\right|^{2}\right]
$$

We know that $u^{*}=\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}$ from the definition of $\Phi_{k, n+1}$ and conclude that $u^{*}$ is continuous, since $\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1} \in C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ by Proposition 2.4. We can thus minimize over continuous functions in (18).

We generalize the minimization problem obtained in Proposition 2.5 by making a change of probability measure. Instead of fixing $y$ we consider the expectation with respect to a probability measure $\mathbb{P}_{Z} \times \mathbb{P}_{Y}$, where $\mathbb{P}_{Z}$ is the distribution of (15), and $\mathbb{P}_{Y}$ can be chosen arbitrarily. However, it is natural to use the measurement model $g$ in the statistical model (2). The obtained solution becomes a deterministic function over $\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right)$, allowing for instantaneous evaluation of new observation sequences, suitable for an online setting. In Section 4 we use neural networks as function approximators and the new optimization problem drops the need of retraining the networks.

Proposition 2.6. Let $Y \in L^{\infty}(\Omega ; \mathbb{Y})$ be a random variable distributed with $\mathbb{P}_{Y}, \bar{\pi}_{k, n+1},(k, n) \in$ $\mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$ be the solutions to (16)-(17) and the functions $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n+1}: \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{R},(k, n) \in$ $\mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$, be the solutions to the recursive optimization problems

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n+1}(x, y)\right)_{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right)} \\
& =\underset{u \in L^{\infty}\left(\operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) ; C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}{\arg \min } \mathbb{E}\left[\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}, Y_{0: k}\right)-G \widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right)\right|^{2}\right] \\
& k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=0,1, \ldots, N-1 \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{0,0}\left(x, y_{0}\right)=q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{k, 0}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)=\widetilde{\pi}_{k-1, N}\left(x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

Then $\widetilde{\pi}$ is well defined and moreover, for all $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, and $y \in \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right)$, we have $\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(y_{0: k}\right)=$ $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\left(y_{0: k}\right)$.

Proof. We remind the reader that $Y$ now represents a random variable with distribution $\mathbb{P}_{Y}$, and hence it is enough to show that $\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(\cdot, Y_{0: k}\right)=\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\left(\cdot, Y_{0: k}\right)$ in $L^{\infty}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})$. We proceed with the proof by using an induction argument. The base case $k=0$ and $n=0$ is trivially valid, since $\bar{\pi}_{0,0}\left(Y_{0}\right)=q_{0} L\left(Y_{0}\right)=\widetilde{\pi}_{0,0}\left(Y_{0}\right)$ by definition, and moreover $x \mapsto q_{0}(x) L(y, x)$ is continuous for every $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ and $(x, y) \mapsto q_{0}(x) L(y, x)$ is bounded. For the induction step, we fix $k \in\{0, \ldots, K-1\}$, $n \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$ and assume that $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n-1}\left(Z_{N-(n-1)}, Y_{0: k}\right)=\bar{\pi}_{k, n-1}\left(Z_{N-(n-1)}, Y_{0: k}\right) \in L^{\infty}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})$. By definition, for a fixed $Y_{0: k}(\omega)=y_{0: k}$, we have

$$
\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, y_{0: k}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[G \bar{\pi}_{k, n-1}\left(Z_{N-(n-1)}, y_{0: k}\right) \mid \mathfrak{S}\left(Z_{N-n}\right)\right]
$$

The minimization problem (19) is solved by the conditional expectation

$$
\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left[G \widetilde{\pi}_{k, n-1}\left(Z_{N-(n-1)}, Y_{0: k}\right) \mid \mathfrak{S}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right)\right]
$$

By the inductive assumption we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right) & =\mathbb{E}\left[G \bar{\pi}_{k, n-1}\left(Z_{N-(n-1)}, Y_{0: k}\right) \mid \mathfrak{S}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[G \bar{\pi}_{k, n-1}\left(Z_{N-(n-1)}, y_{0: k}\right) \mid \mathfrak{S}\left(Z_{N-n}\right)\right]\left.\right|_{y_{0: k}=Y_{0: k}} \\
& =\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(Z_{N-n}, Y_{0: k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $x \mapsto \bar{\pi}_{k, n}(x, y)$ is continuous for all $y \in \mathbb{Y}$, then so is $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}$, as we have shown that they coincide for $y \in \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) \subset \mathbb{Y}$.

The next result is our second main result. It is a direct consequence of Theorem 2.1 and Proposition 2.6 .

Corollary 2.1. Let $p_{k}, k=0, \ldots, K$, be the solution to (5) and $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (19). For $\tau:=\frac{T}{K N} \leq 1$, there exists $C:=C(T, \mu, \sigma, L, K)>0$, such that

$$
\sup _{\substack{k=0, \ldots, K \\ n=0, \ldots, N}}\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \leq C \tau
$$

2.5. Convergence of deep splitting approximation of the Fokker-Planck equation. In this section we harvest the fruits of our analysis for the Fokker-Planck equation alone, disconnected from any filtering problem. For this purpose we take $K=1$, denote by a slight abuse of notation, $t_{k, n}$ by $t_{n}$ and notice that $0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{N}=T$ with uniform time step $\tau=T / N$. The reader can verify that all our proofs are valid for $L \equiv 1$, corresponding to no update and only prediction. From Theorem 2.1, Proposition 2.4, and Propositions 2.1 and 2.5 we can conclude the following theorem.

Theorem 2.2. Let $p \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{1, \infty}\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ be the solution to the Fokker-Planck equation

$$
p(t)=q_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} A^{*} p(s) \mathrm{d} s, \quad t \in[0, T]
$$

and $\bar{\pi}_{n} \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right), n=0, \ldots, N-1$, defined by the minimization problems

$$
\left(\bar{\pi}_{n+1}(x)\right)_{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}=\underset{u \in C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}{\arg \min } \mathbb{E}\left[\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}\right)-G \bar{\pi}_{n}\left(Z_{N-n}\right)\right|^{2}\right], \quad n=0, \ldots, N-1
$$

where $Z_{n}, n=0, \ldots, N$, is the Euler-Maruyama approximation

$$
Z_{n+1}=Z_{n}+\mu\left(Z_{n}\right)\left(t_{n+1}-t_{n}\right)+\sigma\left(Z_{n}\right)\left(W_{t_{n+1}}-W_{t_{n}}\right), \quad n=0, \ldots, N-1
$$

with $Z_{0} \sim \widetilde{q}_{0}$. For $\tau:=\frac{T}{N} \leq 1$, there exists $C:=C(T, \mu, \sigma)>0$ such that

$$
\sup _{n=0, \ldots, N}\left\|p\left(t_{n}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)} \leq C \tau
$$

# 3. CONVERGENCE PROofs 

This section is devoted to the error analysis of the obtained approximation scheme in Proposition 2.6. Section 3.1 contains some preliminaries used for the analysis. In Section 3.2 we state and prove two auxiliary lemmas which are used in Section 3.3 to prove Lemma 2.1 and Lemma 2.2.
3.1. Preliminaries for the analysis. We remind the reader that throughout this section we assume the setting of Section 2.2. For convenience in the later proofs we rewrite the operator $F$ by defining $f_{0}: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and $f_{1}: \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{d}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{0}(x) & =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{d} \frac{\partial^{2} a_{i j}(x)}{\partial x_{i} \partial x_{j}}-\sum_{i=1}^{d} \frac{\partial \mu_{i}(x)}{\partial x_{i}} \\
f_{1}^{j}(x) & =\sum_{i=1}^{d} \frac{\partial a_{i j}(x)}{\partial x_{i}}-2 \mu_{j}(x), \quad j=1, \ldots, d
\end{aligned}
$$

With these functions, we can write $F$, acting on a function $\phi \in C^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, in the form

$$
(F \phi)(x)=f_{0}(x) \phi(x)+f_{1}(x) \cdot \nabla \phi(x), \quad x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

From Assumption (i) of Section 2.2, Proposition 2.1, and Proposition 2.4, we define uniform bounding constants $C_{\phi}=\max _{|n| \leq 4}\left\|D^{\alpha} \phi\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}$ for $\phi=f_{0}, L$, and $\bar{\pi}_{k, n}$, for $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$. Since $p_{k}(y) \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{1, \infty}\left(\left[t_{k, 0}, t_{k+1,0}\right] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ ) for all $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ and $k=0, \ldots, K-1, p_{k}$ is Lipschitz in time, i.e., there exists a constant $C_{p}>0$ such that

$$
\left.22\left\|p_{k}\left(t, y_{0: k}\right)-p_{k}\left(s, y_{0: k}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)} \leq C_{p}[t-s], \quad s, t \in\left[t_{k, 0}, t_{k+1,0}\right], k=0, \ldots, K-1, y \in \mathbb{Y}\right.
$$

where we note that $\|\phi\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}=\|\phi\|_{C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}$ for $\phi \in C_{\mathrm{b}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$.
In the error analysis in Section 3.2, the gradient of the error appears in some of the terms, making a recursive argument infeasible. This is handled by a stochastic integration-by-parts argument in the following lemma. The proof is based on techniques from the Malliavin calculus. An outline of the proof is presented in Appendix A.

Lemma 3.1. There exists a constant $C_{\mathcal{M}}>0$ such that for all $\phi \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla \phi\left(X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right| \leq C_{\mathcal{M}} & \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\phi\left(X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, \quad s, t \in\left(t_{N}-t_{n+1}, t_{N}-t_{n}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

3.2. Local convergence. In preparation for the proofs of Lemma 2.1 and Lemma 2.2, we first state and prove two lemmas. All the estimations in the proofs hold uniformly with respect to $y \in \mathbb{Y}$, and to emphasize the spatial dependence we write $p_{k}(t)(x)$ instead of $p_{k}(t, x, y)$.

Lemma 3.2. Let $p_{k}, k=0, \ldots, K$, be the solution to (5) and $\pi_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (13) and (14). There exists $C_{3}, C_{4}>0$, such that for all $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$, we have

$$
\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}\right)-\pi_{k, n+1}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \leq C_{3} \tau^{2}+\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

Proof. Let $y \in \mathbb{Y}$, and $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$ be fixed, and let $y$ be hidden in the notation. We begin by recalling, from Proposition 2.2 and (13), the Feynman-Kac representations

$$
p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}\right)(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)+\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]
$$

and

$$
\pi_{k, n+1}(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[G \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)+\tau F \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]
$$

Using these expressions and the triangle inequality we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n+1}\right)-\pi_{k, n+1}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)} \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right| \\
& \quad+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} s-\tau F \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right|=I+I I .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term we use the triangle inequality and take a supremum over $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ inside the expectation to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{I} \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right|\right] \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{z \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)(\bar{z})-\pi_{k, n}(z)\right|\right] \\
& \quad=\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)(x)-\pi_{k, n}(x)\right| \leq\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

This fits the form of the recursive bound in Lemma 3.2. The second term is handled by adding and subtracting $F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \tau$, and applying the triangle inequality to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{II} \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mid \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} s-\tau F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right] \\
& \quad+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\tau F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\tau F \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right|=\mathrm{II}_{1}+\mathrm{II}_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

By substituting $F$ as in (21) and the triangle inequality we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{II}_{2} \leq \tau \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[f_{0}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right] \\
& \quad+\tau \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[f_{1}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right| .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term we use the uniform bound $C_{f_{0}}$ and follow the steps in (25). For the second term we apply the bound (23). Hence, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{II}_{2} \leq\left(C_{f_{0}}+C_{\mathcal{M}}\right) \tau\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

This is of the form required in Lemma 3.2.
It remains to show $\mathrm{II}_{1} \leq C \tau^{2}$. By the linearity of the integral we have

$$
\mathrm{II}_{1}=\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mid \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}}\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s\right] \mid
$$

By adding and subtracting $F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)$ and applying the triangle inequality we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Pi_{1} \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}}\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]\right| \\
& \quad+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}}\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]\right|=\Pi_{1,1}+\Pi_{1,2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For the first term we observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Pi_{1,1}=\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}}\left(f_{0}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.\quad+f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} f_{0}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]\right| \\
& \quad+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]\right| .
\end{aligned}
$$

By the Fubini-Tonelli theorem we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Pi_{1,1} \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[f_{0}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} s\right| \\
& \quad+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} s\right| .
\end{aligned}
$$

The condition of absolute integrability of the integrand to use Fubini-Tonelli can be verified by using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, uniform bounds on $f_{0}$ and $f_{1}$, and Lipschitz property of $p$. In the next step we use the uniform bound on $f_{0}$ from assumption (i) and the bound in (23) from Lemma 3.1. Hence, we obtain

$$
\Pi_{1,1} \leq\left(C_{f_{0}}+C_{\mathcal{M}}\right) \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathrm{~d} s\right)
$$

By a uniform bound and substitution in the time variable we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\left(p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathrm{~d} s \\
& \quad \leq \int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}}\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, N}-s\right)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R})} \mathrm{d} s=\int_{t_{k, n}}^{t_{k, n+1}}\left\|p_{k}(s)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)} \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

Recalling the Lipschitz continuity in time (22) we obtain

$$
\int_{t_{k, n}}^{t_{k, n+1}}\left\|p_{k}(s)-p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)} \mathrm{d} s \leq C_{p} \int_{t_{k, n}}^{t_{k, n+1}}\left(s-t_{k, n}\right) \mathrm{d} s=\frac{1}{2} C_{p} \tau^{2}
$$

Inserting this in (26) we get

$$
\Pi_{1,1} \leq \frac{1}{2}\left(C_{f_{0}}+C_{\mathcal{M}}\right) C_{p} \tau^{2}
$$

For the term $\Pi_{1,2}$, we apply Itô's formula to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)=-\int_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} A\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{r}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} r \\
& \quad-\int_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n}}\left\langle\nabla\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{r}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right), \sigma\left(X_{r}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{r}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

We note that the second term is a square integrable martingale with respect to $\mathcal{F}_{s}$, since the integrand is uniformly bounded, and hence it vanishes under the conditional expectation. We

apply the Fubini-Tonelli theorem to change the order of the conditional expectation and time integral in $\Pi_{1,2}$, and then insert the right hand side of (27)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Pi_{1,2} & =\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right)\right] \mathrm{d} s\right| \\
& =\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\int_{t_{N}-t_{n+1}}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n}} A\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)\left(X_{r}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \mathrm{d} r\right] \mathrm{d} s\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

We recall that $p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)(y) \in C_{b}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ uniformly with respect to $y \in \mathbb{Y}$, hence $A\left(F p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)\right)$ is uniformly bounded by some constant $C>0$ depending on $\mu, \sigma$ and derivatives of $p$ of order up to three. We use this bounding constant to obtain

$$
\Pi_{1,2} \leq \frac{1}{2} C \tau^{2}
$$

Thus, we have shown that $\Pi_{1,2}$ and hence $\Pi_{1}$ is bounded as required. Since the obtained bounds are uniform in $y$, we can finish by taking supremum over $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ on the left hand side to obtain (24).

Lemma 3.3. Let $\pi_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (13) and (14), and $\bar{\pi}_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, be the solution to (16) and (17). There exists $C_{5}, C_{6}>0$, such that for all $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$, we have

$$
\left\|\pi_{k, n+1}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \leq C_{5} \tau^{2}+\left(1+C_{6} \tau\right)\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

Proof. We start by fixing $y \in \mathbb{Y},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$ and show that the convergence rate is independent of $y$. Recalling the solution $\pi$ to (13) and the solution $\bar{\pi}$ to (16) satisfy the recursive relations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \pi_{k, n+1}(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G \pi_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right] \\
& \bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right)\left(Z_{N-n}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

we obtain

$$
\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\pi_{k, n+1}(x)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}(x)\right|=\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G \pi_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\left(G \bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}\right)\left(Z_{N-n}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right|
$$

We add and subtract $\left(G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)$ and apply the triangle inequality to get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\pi_{k, n+1}(x)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n+1}(x)\right| \leq & \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G \pi_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\left(G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right| \\
& \left.+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right)\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\left(G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right)\left(Z_{N-n}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right|=I+I I .
\end{aligned}
$$

By the definition (12) of $G$ and the triangle inequality we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{I} \leq & \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right| \\
& \left.+\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\tau\left(F \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-F \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right)\right]\right|=\mathrm{I}_{1}+\mathrm{I}_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying analogue steps to (25), we obtain

$$
\mathrm{I}_{1} \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right|\right] \leq\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

This is one of the terms on the right hand side in the bound in Lemma 3.3. For the second term $\mathrm{I}_{2}$, substituting $F$ as in (21) and applying the triangle inequality, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{I}_{2}= & \tau \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[f_{0}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\left(\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right)\right]\right| \\
& +\tau \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[f_{1}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot\left(\nabla \pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)-\nabla \bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right)\right]\right|=\tau\left(\mathrm{I}_{2,1}+\mathrm{I}_{2,2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It remains to show that

$$
\mathrm{I}_{2,1}+\mathrm{I}_{2,2} \leq C\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

The term $\mathrm{I}_{2,1}$ is dealt with by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and using the uniform bound from assumption (i). This gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{I}_{2,1} & \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|f_{0}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \leq C_{f_{0}} \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, using the inequality in (28), we get

$$
\mathrm{I}_{2,1} \leq C_{f_{0}}\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

For the term $\mathrm{I}_{2,2}$ we apply Lemma 3.1 and the bound (23) to get

$$
\mathrm{I}_{2,2} \leq C_{\mathcal{M}} \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\pi_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\left(X_{t_{N}-t_{n}}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, \bar{x}}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

By (28) we obtain

$$
\mathrm{I}_{2,2} \leq C_{\mathcal{M}}\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

Combining (30) and (31), we conclude (29). Thus we have shown

$$
I \leq\left(1+\left(C_{\mathcal{M}}+C_{f_{0}}\right) \tau\right)\left\|\pi_{k, n}-\bar{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
$$

The term II is the weak error for the Euler-Maruyama approximation of $X$ with test function $G \bar{\pi}_{k, n}$. Compared to the standard setting the error is now only over one time step and it is therefore $O\left(\tau^{2}\right)$ instead of $O(\tau)$. We omit the proof which can be found in, e.g., [25, Theorem 5.3.1]. For a constant $C>0$ that depends on $\mu, \sigma$ and $C_{\bar{\Psi}}$ we get

$$
\text { II } \leq C \tau^{2}
$$

We conclude the proof by taking supremum over $y \in \mathbb{Y}$ on the left hand side.
3.3. Global convergence. This section is devoted to proving the convergence in Lemma 2.1. The arguments in the following proof can be adapted, using Lemma 3.3, to prove Lemma 2.2.

Proof of Lemma 2.1. We define $e_{k, n}:=\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\pi_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{Y} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}$, so that Lemma 3.2 can be summarized, with this notation, as

$$
e_{k, n} \leq C_{3} \tau^{2}+\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right) e_{k, n-1}, \quad k=0, \ldots, K-1, n=1, \ldots, N
$$

We next prove a bound at the update time $t_{k, 0}$, where we have

$$
p_{k}\left(t_{k, 0}, y_{0: k}\right)-\pi_{k, 0}\left(y_{0: k}\right)=\left(p_{k-1}\left(t_{k, 0}, y_{0: k-1}\right)-\pi_{k-1, N}\left(y_{0: k-1}\right)\right) L\left(y_{k}\right)
$$

Using the fact that $t_{k, 0}=t_{k-1, N}$ we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, 0}, y_{0: k}\right)-\pi_{k, 0}\left(y_{0: k}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)} \\
& \quad \leq\left\|L\left(y_{k}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k-1, N}, y_{0: k-1}\right)-\pi_{k-1, N}\left(y_{0: k-1}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We take supremum over $\mathbb{Y}$ and use the uniform bound on $L$, to obtain

$$
e_{k, 0} \leq C_{L} e_{k-1, N}
$$

Inequalities (32) and (33) are next used to complete the proof and we begin by fixing $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$. Repeating (32) over $n$ steps, we get

$$
e_{k, n} \leq C_{3} \tau^{2} \sum_{\ell=0}^{n-1}\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{\ell}+\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{n} e_{k, 0}
$$

By recalling $\tau=\frac{T}{K N}$, we note that, for $N \geq 1$,

$$
\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{N-1} \leq \exp \left(C_{4} T K^{-1}\right)
$$

Applying the well-known formula for geometric sums and by (35) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{3} \tau^{2} \sum_{\ell=0}^{n-1}(1 & \left.+C_{4} \tau\right)^{\ell} \leq C_{3} \tau^{2} \sum_{\ell=0}^{N-1}\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{\ell}=C_{3} \tau^{2} \frac{\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{N-1}-1}{\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)-1} \\
& =C_{3} C_{4}^{-1}\left(\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{N-1}-1\right) \tau \leq C_{3} C_{4}^{-1}\left(\exp \left(C_{4} T K^{-1}\right)-1\right) \tau=: c_{1} \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

This gives a bound for the first term of (34). For the second term we use (33), (35) to get

$$
\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{n} e_{k, 0} \leq\left(1+C_{4} \tau\right)^{N} e_{k, 0} \leq C_{L} \exp \left(C_{4} T K^{-1}\right) e_{k-1, N}=: c_{2} e_{k-1, N}
$$

To sum up, we have

$$
e_{k, n} \leq c_{1} \tau+c_{2} e_{k-1, N}
$$

Repeating this procedure $k$ times we obtain

$$
e_{k, n} \leq c_{1} \tau \sum_{\ell=0}^{k-1} c_{2}^{\ell}+c_{2}^{k} e_{0,0}
$$

Since $\pi_{0}=q_{0}$ the second term vanishes. Introducing $C=c_{1} \sum_{\ell=0}^{K} c_{2}^{\ell}$ we obtain

$$
e_{k, n} \leq c_{1} \tau \sum_{\ell=0}^{K} c_{2}^{\ell}=C \tau
$$

This completes the proof of Lemma 2.1.

# 4. NUMERICAL EXPERIMENTS 

In this section we examine the strong convergence order of $\widetilde{\pi}$ numerically. We begin by reminding that the convergence in Corollary 2.1 holds for all $y \in \operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right)$, and in this section we fix $Y=O$, defined in the statistical model (2), and let $\widetilde{q}_{0}=q_{0}$. First, in Section 4.1, we detail the final approximation steps needed to perform the numerical experiments. In Section 4.2 we describe the approximation of the left hand side in Theorem 2.1. Finally, in Section 4.3 we demonstrate convergence on two one-dimensional examples.
4.1. Energy-based approximation. In the previous work [3], the Energy-Based Deep Splitting (EBDS) method was employed on the Zakai equation, solving the filtering problem with continuous in time observations. Here we adapt the same approximation procedures. The initial step involves approximating the expectation in (19) using a Monte Carlo average. This consists of sampling $M$ independent pairs $\left(Z_{0: N}^{m}, Y_{0: K}^{m}\right)_{m=1}^{M}$ from (15) and (2) respectively. The updated problem reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\left(\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n+1}^{M}(x, y)\right)_{(x, y) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)}}\right. \\
& =\underset{u \in C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}{\arg \min } \frac{1}{M} \sum_{m=1}^{M}\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}^{m}, Y_{0: k}^{m}\right)-G \widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M}\left(Z_{N-n}^{m}, Y_{0: k}^{m}\right)\right|^{2} \\
& k=0, \ldots, K-1, \quad n=0, \ldots, N-1 \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{0,0}^{M}\left(x, y_{0}\right)=q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{k, 0}^{M}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)=\widetilde{\pi}_{k-1, N}^{M}\left(x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

Approximating expectations with Monte Carlo averages is a classical technique and by the central limit theorem one can, for well behaved integrands, expect a convergence of order $\frac{1}{2}$ in $M$.
The second step is to approximate $C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$ by a neural network, more precisely, by the space $\left\{\mathcal{N}_{\theta}: \theta \in \Theta_{k}\right\} \subset C\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. Here every $\theta$ in the space of parameters $\Theta_{k} \subset \mathbb{R}^{\left(d+d^{\prime} \times(k+1)\right) \times J^{E} \times 1}$ defines a continuous function $\mathcal{N}_{\theta}$, a Fully Connected Neural Network (FCNN) with $\mathfrak{L}$ hidden layers and a width of $J$ neurons, mapping $\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)}$ to $\mathbb{R}$. In this work we use ReLU activation functions between each hidden layer except the final one, for which we instead use an energy-based activation described below. Other constructions with more advanced (or simpler) architectures could be of interest in future work, but here the focus lies on examining

the convergence order numerically rather than on optimized architectures. The new optimization problem reads

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\left(\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n+1}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}(x, y)\right)_{\{x, y\} \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)}}\right. \\
& \quad=\underset{u \in\left\{\mathcal{N}_{\mathcal{S}}: \theta \in \Theta_{k}\right\}}{\arg \min } \frac{1}{M} \sum_{m=1}^{M}\left|u\left(Z_{N-(n+1)}^{m}, Y_{0: k}^{m}\right)-G \widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\left(Z_{N-n}^{m}, Y_{0: k}^{m}\right)\right|^{2} \\
& k=0, \ldots, K-1, \quad n=0, \ldots, N-1 \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{0,0}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\left(x, y_{0}\right)=q_{0}(x) L\left(y_{0}, x\right) \\
& \widetilde{\pi}_{k, 0}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)=\widetilde{\pi}_{k-1, N}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\left(x, y_{0: k-1}\right) L\left(y_{k}, x\right), \quad k=1, \ldots, K
\end{aligned}
$$

In [47] it is shown how well FCNNs approximate functions in Sobolev spaces. Specifically, with a fixed width $J$, it can be shown that the approximation converges with order $\mathfrak{L}^{-\gamma}$, where $J$ and $\gamma>0$ depend on the underlying dimension $d$ and the regularity of the Sobolev space.

The energy-based activation layer mentioned above consists of taking a scalar output $f_{\theta}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)$ through the exponential function. That is, we let the normalized conditional density be approximated, for each $\theta \in \Theta_{k}$ and input pair $\left(x, y_{0: k}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime} \times(k+1)}$, by

$$
p\left(x \mid y_{0: k}\right) \approx \frac{\mathcal{N}_{\theta}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)}{Z_{\theta}\left(y_{0: k}\right)}
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{N}_{\theta}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)=\mathrm{e}^{-f_{\theta}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)}, \quad Z_{\theta}\left(y_{0: k}\right)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \mathrm{e}^{-f_{\theta}\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)} \mathrm{d} z
$$

There are two main ideas behind the use of energy-based activation for probabilistic modeling. The first is that we do not have to evaluate the normalizing constant $Z_{\theta}$, if we are only concerned with the unnormalized density. This speeds up training and still learns the density. The second concerns the scalar energy $f_{\theta}$. The idea is that it should assign low energy (resulting in a high probability) to pairs $\left(x, y_{0: k}\right)$, that are more likely to occur and high energy (resulting in low probability) to pairs that are less likely to occur. This fits very well with solving (36), where it is enough to approximate an unnormalized solution of the Fokker-Planck equation (5) and to do the normalization in the inference stage. Trivially, this activation guarantees positive values which is a crucial when approximating probabilities. One can also construct $f_{\theta}$ in such a way that it guarantees that $Z_{\theta}$ is finite, e.g., by learning Gaussian tails [3]. Finally, we employ the time reparametrization that was done in [3, Section 3.4], which defines an equivalent optimization problem that is more suitable for computations.
4.2. Evaluation. The objective of Section 4 is to numerically examine the convergence order of the approximation $\widetilde{\pi}$. To do this, we need to approximate the left hand side of (20). Subsection 4.1 introduces the approximation $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}$ of $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}$. For numerical stability, we incorporate a normalization of $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, 0}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\left(Y_{0: k}^{m}\right)$, for all $k=0, \ldots, K$ and $m=1, \ldots, M$ in the training process before training each subsequent network. In Section 4.3 we evaluate the strong error in two 1-dimensional examples and the normalization is done with quadrature. Now, we measure the error between $p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)$ and $\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}$ in $L^{2}\left(\Omega ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)$ for fixed $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$. By the triangle inequality and by estimating the $L^{2}$-norm by the $L^{\infty}$-norm, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\Omega ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} \\
& \quad \leq\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}+\left\|\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathfrak{L}}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\operatorname{supp}\left(\mathbb{P}_{Y}\right) ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We see that the first term on the right hand side of (37) is the left hand side in Corollary 2.1.
