The second term is the error that occurs due to the statistical approximation depending on $M$ and the approximation error by the neural network depending on $\mathfrak{L}$. In Subsection 4.3 we set $M$ and $\mathfrak{L}$ sufficiently large such that the first term on the right hand side of (37) is the dominating error.

We need further approximations to evaluate the left hand side of (37), which is, for $(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N}$, defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathcal{L}}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(1 \mathrm{~S} ; L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)\right)} & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, Y_{0: k}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathcal{L}}\left(Y_{0: k}\right)\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)}^{2}\right. \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, x, Y_{0: k}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathcal{L}}\left(x, Y_{0: k}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

To evaluate (38), we first approximate the expectation with $M_{\mathrm{e}}$ Monte Carlo samples from (2). Secondly, since we are only evaluating this in $d=1$, we approximate the supremum by taking the supremum over a uniform grid $B$ in a bounded domain of $\mathbb{R}$, where the solutions have most of their mass. Combining the approximations, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}}\left|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, x, Y_{0: k}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathcal{L}}\left(x, Y_{0: k}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \quad \approx\left(\frac{1}{M_{\mathrm{e}}} \sum_{m_{\mathrm{e}}=1}^{M_{\mathrm{e}}} \sup _{x \in B}\left|p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}, x, Y_{0: k}^{m_{\mathrm{e}}}\right)-\widetilde{\pi}_{k, n}^{M, \mathcal{L}}\left(x, Y_{0: k}^{m_{\mathrm{e}}}\right)\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The approximation error becomes arbitrarily small by choosing $|B|$ and $M_{\mathrm{e}}$ large enough.
4.3. Numerical convergence. In this section we empirically examine the convergence order of the EBDS method applied to two one-dimensional examples. The first one is a drifted Brownian motion that satisfies the assumptions in Section 2.2. The other is a bistable process, characterized by two modes in its corresponding probability distribution, and does not satisfy the assumptions. In both examples, we have $q_{0}=\mathcal{N}(0,1), \sigma(x)=1$, Gaussian measurements $Y_{k} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(h\left(S_{t_{k, 0}}\right), R\right)$ with measurement function $h(x)=x$ and variance $R=1$. It is worth mentioning that this corresponds to a rather low signal-to-noise ratio, which some would argue is a harder problem. The drifted Brownian motion process has a drift coefficient $\mu(x)=2$, while the bistable process has a drift coefficient $\mu(x)=\frac{2}{5}\left(5 x-x^{3}\right)$. In both cases, we use $K=20$ with equidistant measurements with a final time of $T=2$. This decision was made based on the observation that the $L^{2}\left(L^{\infty}\right)$-error reaches a relatively stable value before $t=2$ for both examples.

To evaluate (39), we need the reference solution $p_{k}\left(t_{k, n}\right)$. In the drifted Brownian motion example, this corresponds to the famous Kalman filter mentioned earlier, see, e.g., [46]. The bistable process with its nonlinearity in the drift has no analytical solution. Instead, we employ a bootstrap particle filter with 10000 particles to find a good approximation of the true solution. Finally, the constants for the numerical evaluation in the drifted Brownian motion example and the bistable example are, respectively: $M_{\mathrm{e}}=\{5000,500\}, J=128, M=10^{6}, \mathfrak{L}=3$ and $|B|=2000$.

In Figure 1 we see the error (39) with 5 different discretizations $N=1,2,4,8,16$ over all time steps $t_{k, n},(k, n) \in \mathcal{I}_{K, N-1}$. Each error trajectory corresponds to the average over 10 runs of the method to better illustrate the performance. It is easy to see how the error decreases by an increasing number of time steps $N$ in both examples. On the dashed lines, at time steps $\left(t_{k, 0}\right)_{k=0}^{K}$, the solutions are updated with new measurements, and we see that the error tends to increase ever so slightly at these time steps. It is not clear why this is the case, and our best guess is that it relates to a slight numerical instability or inaccuracy during normalization. We can also observe that, in the two examples, the drifted Brownian motion example reaches a steady-state error more quickly for all discretizations.

Looking at the final time $T=2$ for the different discretizations, we see the convergence in Figure 2. In the figure, we see 10 instances of the performed algorithm, obtaining 10 slightly different approximations due to stochastic gradient descent, illustrated in red. The figure has a logarithmic scale and shows that the average error, illustrated in blue, decreases with about order 1 for the drifted Brownian motion example and with about order $\frac{1}{2}$ for the bistable example compared to the reference lines of $O\left(N^{-1}\right)$ and $O\left(N^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)$, where $N=\frac{2}{K \tau}$.
This indicates that the assumptions in Section 2.2 are crucial for order 1 convergence and that order $\frac{1}{2}$ might be possible under weaker assumptions.

# Appendix A. Malliavin integration by parts 

Here we prove Lemma 3.1 by means of Malliavin integration by parts. This proof follows the notes of [35]; similar material can be found in [27] or [41]. This is provided for the reader to easier understand the results of this paper and to get a short introduction to Malliavin calculus. We follow [35] and start with some notation.

We let $H$ denote a separable Hilbert space and $H^{\otimes n}$ be the $n$-fold tensor product of $H$. For $H$ being the space $L^{2}\left(I ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ for $I \subset \mathbb{R}$, which is the case we are interested in, the tensor product space is realized as $L^{2}\left(I^{a} ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$. Furthermore, we let $W$ be an $H$-isonormal Gaussian process on a probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{A}, \mathbb{P})$. That is, a family $W=\{W(h): h \in H\}$ of real-valued random variables such that each $W(h)$ is Gaussian and $\mathbb{E}[W(h) W(g)]=\langle h, g\rangle_{H}$. One can show that such $W$ exists. If $H=L^{2}(I ; \mathbb{R})$, then $B_{t}=W\left(I_{(0, t)}\right)$ is a Brownian motion and $\int_{0}^{t} f_{s} \mathrm{~d} B_{s}=W\left(I_{(0, t)} f\right)$ is the Wiener integral. Now we define $\mathcal{S}$ as the space of smooth random variables having the form

$$
F=f\left(W\left(h_{1}\right), W\left(h_{2}\right), \ldots, W\left(h_{n}\right)\right)
$$

for some $f \in C_{b}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; \mathbb{R}\right), h_{1}, \ldots, h_{n} \in H$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$. We note that $\mathcal{S}$ is dense in $L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})$. Now, by $D F$ we denote the Malliavin derivative of $F$ as the $H$-valued random variable defined by

$$
D F=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \partial_{j} f\left(W\left(h_{1}\right), W\left(h_{2}\right), \ldots, W\left(h_{n}\right)\right) h_{j}
$$

It can be shown that the operator $D$ is closable in $L^{p}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}) \rightarrow L^{p}(\Omega ; H)$ and with a slight abuse of notation we will denote the closure of $D$ with $D$. We denote the domain of $D$, for each $p \geq 1$,

by $\mathbb{D}^{1, p}=\{F \in \mathcal{S}:\|F\|_{\mathbb{D}^{1, p}}<\infty\}$, where

$$
\|F\|_{\mathbb{D}^{1, p}}=\left(\mathbb{E}|F|^{p}+\mathbb{E}\|D F\|_{H}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

It follows that $\mathbb{D}^{1, p}$ is the closure of $\mathcal{S}$ with respect to the above norm. We inductively define the space $\mathbb{D}^{k, p}=\left\{F \in \mathbb{D}^{k-1, p}: D F \in \mathbb{D}^{k-1, p}\right\}$ such that $D^{k} F=D\left(D^{k-1} F\right)$, where the norm is defined by

$$
\|F\|_{\mathbb{D}^{k, p}}=\left(\mathbb{E}|F|^{p}+\sum_{j=1}^{k} \mathbb{E}\left\|D^{j} F\right\|_{H \pi j}^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

Additionally, we define the space

$$
\mathbb{D}^{\infty}=\bigcap_{k=1}^{\infty} \bigcap_{p \geq 1} \mathbb{D}^{k, p}
$$

Next, we define the divergence operator $\delta$, sometimes called the Skorohod integral, adjoint to the Malliavin derivative $D: L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}) \rightarrow L^{2}(\Omega ; H)$. Its domain $\operatorname{dom}(\delta) \subset L^{2}(\Omega ; H)$ is defined as all $u \in L^{2}(\Omega ; H)$ such that there exists a $G \in L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})$ that satisfies, for all $Y \in \mathbb{D}^{1,2}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\langle D Y, u\rangle_{H}=\mathbb{E}[Y G]
$$

and we set $\delta(u):=G$. In the case $H=L^{2}(I ; \mathbb{R})$ and $u \in \operatorname{dom}(\delta)$ being an adapted process, we have $\delta(u)=\int_{I} u_{s} \mathrm{~d} B_{s}$, the Itô integral.

The Malliavin matrix with respect to a random variable $F=\left(F_{1}, \ldots, F_{m}\right)$ in $H$ is the random matrix

$$
\mathcal{M}=\left(\left\langle D F_{i}, D F_{j}\right\rangle_{H}\right)_{i, j=1}^{m}
$$

The following proposition is quoted from [35, Proposition 2.2.4].
Proposition A.1. Let $F \in L^{2}\left(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}^{m}\right)$ satisfy $F_{j} \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$ for all $j=1, \ldots, m$ such that $D F \in$ $L^{2}\left(\Omega ; H^{m \times 1}\right)$ and the Malliavin matrix $\mathcal{M}$ satisfies $(\operatorname{det} \mathcal{M})^{-1} \in L^{p}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})$ for all $p \geq 1$. Then we have for $\varphi \in C_{\mathrm{p}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}\right), Y \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$, and $j=1, \ldots, m$ that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[Y \partial_{j} \varphi(F)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{j} \varphi(F)\right]
$$

where $Z_{j}$ is defined by

$$
Z_{j}=\delta\left(Y\left(\mathcal{M}^{-1} D F\right)_{j}\right)
$$

and belongs to $\mathbb{D}^{\infty}$.

It is convenient to reformulate this using matrix notation. We see by the linearity of the expectation and the Skorohod integral and by summing over $j=1, \ldots, m$, with $Y=\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{m}\right)$, where $Y_{j} \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$, that we have

$$
\mathbb{E}[\nabla \varphi(F) \cdot Y]=\mathbb{E}\left[\delta\left(Y \cdot \mathcal{M}^{-1} D F\right) \varphi(F)\right]
$$

We now connect with the notation in (6) and Lemma 3.1. There the dimensions of the state variable $X$ and the driving Browian motion $W$ are the same. For pedagogical reasons, we here let the dimension of $X$ be $m$ and that of $W$ be $d$; hence, $\sigma$ is of type $m \times d$. We define $X_{t}=X_{t}^{\dagger_{N}-t_{n+1}, \mathcal{E}} \in$ $L^{2}\left(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}^{m}\right), t \in\left[t_{N}-t_{n+1}, t_{N}-t_{n}\right]$, and without loss of generality we assume that $t_{N}-t_{n+1}=0$, so that it is enough to consider a Hilbert space $H=L^{2}\left([0, T] ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$. In this space, we let, with a slight abuse of notation, $W=\left(W^{1}, \ldots, W^{d}\right)$ denote a Brownian motion defined by the $H$-isonormal Gaussian process, where $W_{t}^{j}=W\left(I_{[0, t]} e_{j}\right)$ and $\left(e_{j}\right)_{j=1}^{d}$ is the standard basis of $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. The Malliavin derivative of a random variable $F \in L^{2}(\Omega, \mathbb{R})$ then becomes $D F \in L^{2}\left(\Omega ; L^{2}\left([0, T] ; \mathbb{R}^{1 \times d}\right)\right)$ (a row vector), which we denote by $(D F)_{a}^{k}, u \in[0, T], k=1, \ldots, d$. Now we want to use Proposition A. 1 for fixed $s, t \in[0, T], F=X_{t} \in L^{2}\left(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}^{m \times 1}\right), Y=f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right) \in L^{2}\left(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}^{m \times 1}\right)$ (column vectors)

and $\varphi=\phi \in C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$. This gives the Malliavin derivative $D X_{t}^{j} \in L^{2}\left(\Omega ; L^{2}\left([0, T] ; \mathbb{R}^{1 \times d}\right)\right)$ for $j=1, \ldots, m$ and $D X_{t} \in L^{2}\left(\Omega ; L^{2}\left([0, T] ; \mathbb{R}^{m \times d}\right)\right.$ with the Malliavin matrix

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{M}_{t}=\left(\left\langle D X_{t}^{i}, D X_{t}^{j}\right\rangle_{L^{2}\left([0, T] ; \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)}\right)_{i, j=1}^{m} & =\left(\int_{0}^{t} \sum_{k=1}^{d}\left(D X_{t}^{i}\right)_{u}^{k}\left(D X_{t}^{j}\right)_{u}^{k} \mathrm{~d} u\right)_{i, j=1}^{m} \\
& =\int_{0}^{t}\left(D X_{t}\right)_{u}\left(D X_{t}\right)_{u}^{\top} \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we use the fact that $\left(D X_{t}\right)_{u}=0$ for $u \geq t$, since $X_{t}$ is $\mathcal{F}_{t}$-measurable. In order to prove Lemma 3.1 we want to apply Proposition A. 1 and for this we need to show, for all $j=1, \ldots, m$, that

$$
\begin{aligned}
X_{t}^{j} & \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty} \\
f_{1}^{j}\left(X_{s}\right) & \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty} \\
\phi & \in C_{\mathrm{p}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}\right) \\
\mathcal{M}_{t}^{-1} & \text { exists and }\left(\operatorname{det} \mathcal{M}_{t}\right)^{-1} \in L^{p}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})
\end{aligned}
$$

Given conditions (41)-(43), by applying (40), we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla \phi\left(X_{t}\right) \cdot f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right)\right]=\left\langle\delta\left(f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right) \cdot \mathcal{M}_{t}^{-1} D X_{t}\right), \phi\left(X_{t}\right)\right\rangle_{L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})}
$$

Proposition A. 1 also states that $\delta\left(f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right) \cdot \mathcal{M}_{t}^{-1} D X_{t}\right) \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$, which implies that there exists a constant $C_{\mathcal{M}}$ such that

$$
\left\|\delta\left(f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right) \cdot \mathcal{M}_{t}^{-1} D X_{t}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})} \leq C_{\mathcal{M}}
$$

Combining this with the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality in (44) we obtain

$$
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla \phi\left(X_{t}\right) \cdot f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right)\right]\right| \leq\left\|\delta\left(f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right) \cdot \mathcal{M}_{t}^{-1} D X_{t}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})}\left\|\phi\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})} \leq C_{\mathcal{M}}\left\|\phi\left(X_{t}\right)\right\|_{L^{2}(\Omega ; \mathbb{R})}
$$

This proves the lemma under the assumption that conditions (41)-(43) hold. The full proof of this is very technical and we refrain from giving all details. Still, we find it useful to give a glimpse of the arguments involved and, therefore, to outline important parts of the proof. For this purpose, we start by citing a result on the Malliavin regularity of SDE with smooth coefficients.

Theorem A. 1 (2.3.6 and 2.3.7 in [35]). Let the drift coefficient $\mu: \mathbb{R}^{m} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$ be in $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}^{m}\right)$ and the diffusion coefficient $\sigma: \mathbb{R}^{m} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m \times d}$ be in $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}^{m \times d}\right), x_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{m}$, and let $\left(X_{t}^{0, x_{0}}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ be the unique adapted process which, for all $t \in[0, T], \mathbb{P}$-almost surely satisfies

$$
X_{t}=x_{0}+\int_{0}^{t} \mu\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t} \sigma\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}
$$

The components $X^{j}$ in $X$ satisfy for all $t \in[0, T]$ that $X_{t}^{j} \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$, and the derivative $D X_{t} \in$ $L^{2}\left(\Omega ; L^{2}\left([0, T] ; \mathbb{R}^{m \times d}\right)\right)$ satisfies for all $s, t \in[0, T]$ with $s \leq t$, $\mathbb{P}$-almost surely

$$
\left(D X_{t}\right)_{s}=\sigma\left(X_{s}\right)+\int_{s}^{t} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{u}\right)\left(D X_{u}\right)_{s} \mathrm{~d} u+\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{s}^{t} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{u}\right)\left(D X_{u}\right)_{s} \mathrm{~d} W_{u}^{j}
$$

For the case $s>t$, we have $\left(D X_{t}\right)_{s}=0$. Here, the derivative $\mu^{\prime}(X) \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}^{m}\right)$, or equivalently an $m \times m$-matrix, and the derivatives $\sigma_{j}^{\prime}(X) \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{R}^{m} ; \mathbb{R}^{m}\right)$, or equivalently an $m \times m$-matrix defining the Jacobian of the $j$ :th column in $\sigma$ for all $j=1, \ldots, d$.

The theorem implies that $X_{t}^{j} \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$ satisfies (41), since $\mu$ and $\sigma$ in (6) belong to $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty}$. Moreover, by [35, Lemma 2.2.1] it holds for $F \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$ and $\varphi \in C^{\infty}$ that $\varphi(F) \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$. Therefore, we conclude that $f_{1}\left(X_{s}\right) \in \mathbb{D}^{\infty}$. Clearly, (42) is fulfilled since $C_{\mathrm{b}}^{\infty} \subset C_{\mathrm{p}}^{\infty}$ and thus it remains to verify the condition (43).

We follow the derivation of [35] closely. To this end, we want to construct a new representation of the Malliavin matrix by the use of an auxiliary process $\left(Y_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$. More specifically we claim that the solution $\left(D X_{t}\right)_{s}$ to (45) can be represented by the evolution operator $Y_{t} Y_{s}^{-1}$ as $\left(D X_{t}\right)_{s}=$

$Y_{t} Y_{s}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{s}\right)$. Here $Y$ is defined as the matrix-valued stochastic process $[0, T] \times \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}$ that for all $t \in[0, T], \mathbb{P}$-almost surely satisfies

$$
Y_{t}=I+\int_{0}^{t} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} \mathrm{~d} s+\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{t} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} \mathrm{~d} W_{s}^{j}
$$

The idea is to show that the new representation of $D X_{t}$ holds and as a consequence find a new representation of the Malliavin matrix $\mathcal{M}_{t}$. Since we are interested in showing that $\mathcal{M}_{t}$ is invertible we first show that $Y$ is invertible and that its inverse has finite moments. By applying Itô's formula to $f(A)=A^{-1}$ with derivatives $f^{\prime}(A)[H]=-A^{-1} H A^{-1}$ and $f^{\prime \prime}(A)[H, H]=2 A^{-1} H A^{-1} H A^{-1}$, we obtain formally that

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{t}^{-1}= & I^{-1}-\int_{0}^{t} Y_{s}^{-1} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} Y_{s}^{-1} \mathrm{~d} s-\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{t} Y_{s}^{-1} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} Y_{s}^{-1} \mathrm{~d} W_{s}^{j} \\
& +\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{t} Y_{s}^{-1} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} Y_{s}^{-1} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} Y_{s}^{-1} \mathrm{~d} s \\
= & I-\int_{0}^{t} Y_{s}^{-1} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{t} Y_{s}^{-1} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}^{j}+\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{t} Y_{s}^{-1}\left(\sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right)\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

If we formulate this as an equation, then we expect $Y_{t}^{-1}$ to be the solution $Z_{t}$ that, for all $t \in[0, T]$, $\mathbb{P}$-almost surely satisfies

$$
Z_{t}=I+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{d} Z_{s}\left(\sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right)\right)^{2}-Z_{s} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s-\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{t} Z_{s} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}^{j}
$$

Since $\mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right)$ and $\sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right)$, for all $j=1, \ldots, d$, are uniformly bounded, the coefficients in (46) are of linear growth and thus satisfy the standard conditions to show existence and uniqueness of an SDE. This guarantees the existence of $Z$ and that its moments of all orders are finite.
Moreover, by applying Itô's formula to $f(A, B)=A B$ one can show that $Z_{t} Y_{t}=I$, and hence showing that $Y_{t}$ is $\mathbb{P}$-almost surely a right-inverse of $Z_{t}$. Analogously this can be done with $f(A, B)=B A$ to show that $Y_{t} Z_{t}=I$ and hence showing that $Y_{t}$ is almost surely invertible with the inverse $Y_{t}^{-1}=Z_{t}$. Finally, we show that for all $r \in[0, t]$ and fixed $t \in[0, T]$ it holds

$$
\left(D X_{t}\right)_{r}=Y_{t} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right)
$$

We do this by inserting the process $t \mapsto Y_{t} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right)$ into the right hand side of (45) and verifying that this gives the correct left hand side. Indeed,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma\left(X_{r}\right) & +\int_{r}^{t} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{r}^{t} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right) \mathrm{d} W_{s}^{j} \\
& =\sigma\left(X_{r}\right)+\left(\int_{r}^{t} \mu^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} \mathrm{~d} s+\sum_{j=1}^{d} \int_{r}^{t} \sigma_{j}^{\prime}\left(X_{s}\right) Y_{s} \mathrm{~d} W_{s}^{j}\right) Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right) \\
& =\sigma\left(X_{r}\right)+\left(Y_{t}-Y_{r}\right) Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right) \\
& =Y_{t} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $Y_{t} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right)$ satisfies the same equation (45) as $\left(D X_{t}\right)_{r}$ for all $r \in[0, t]$ and $t \in[0, T]$. Using the new representation (47) of $\left(D X_{t}\right)_{r}$, the Malliavin matrix $\mathcal{M}_{t}$ satisfies

$$
\mathcal{M}_{t}=\int_{0}^{t}\left(D X_{t}\right)_{r}\left(D X_{t}\right)_{r}^{\top} \mathrm{d} r=\int_{0}^{t} Y_{t} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right) \sigma\left(X_{r}\right)^{\top}\left(Y_{r}^{-1}\right)^{\top} Y_{t}^{\top} \mathrm{d} r=Y_{t} C_{t} Y_{t}^{\top}
$$

Here we have defined $C_{t}$ for all $t \in[0, T]$ as

$$
C_{t}:=\int_{0}^{t} Y_{r}^{-1} \sigma\left(X_{r}\right) \sigma\left(X_{r}\right)^{\top}\left(Y_{r}^{-1}\right)^{\top} \mathrm{d} r
$$

We recall that the inverse $Y_{t}^{-1}$ exists and has finite moments of all orders. This implies, with Hölder's inequality on $\left\|Y_{t} C_{t} Y_{t}^{\top}\right\|_{L^{p}}$, that its enough to prove that $C_{t}$ is invertible with finite moments on its determinant to prove that this also holds for $\mathcal{M}_{t}$. To this end we state the following lemma whose proof can be found in [35].

Lemma A. 1 (2.4.4 [35]). Let $M$ be a random symmetric positive semidefinite matrix with entries in $\bigcap_{p} L^{p}(\Omega)$. Assume that, for all $p \geq 2$, there exist a constant $C_{p}$ and an $\epsilon_{p}>0$, such that, for all $\epsilon \in\left(0, \epsilon_{p}\right)$, we have

$$
\sup _{\|x\|=1} \mathbb{P}\left(x^{\top} M x \leq \epsilon\right) \leq C_{p} \epsilon^{p}
$$

Then $(\operatorname{det} M)^{-1} \in \bigcap_{p \geq 1} L^{p}(\Omega)$.
One can show that $C_{t}$ satisfies the conditions of this lemma, which implies the desired result that $\left(\operatorname{det} C_{t}\right)^{-1} \in L^{p}(\Omega)$ for all $p$. We omit the proof and refer to [35, Theorem 2.4.5] for a technical proof building on a Hörmander condition and concepts of "almost implications". It is worth noting that the parabolic Hörmander condition (4) that we assume in Section 2 is a sufficient condition for this to hold. We have thus highlighted parts of the proof of the following result, which implies Lemma 3.1.

Lemma A.2. Under assumptions (i) and (ii), for $\phi \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} ; \mathbb{R}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla \phi\left(X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\delta\left(f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \mathcal{M}_{t}^{-1} D X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \phi\left(X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right] \\
x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, \quad s, t \in\left(t_{N}-t_{n+1}, t_{N}-t_{n}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, there exists a constant $C_{\mathcal{M}}>0$, such that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[f_{1}\left(X_{s}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right) \cdot \nabla \phi\left(X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right]\right| \leq C_{\mathcal{M}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left.\left|\phi\left(X_{t}^{t_{N}-t_{n+1}, x}\right)\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right. \\
x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, \quad s, t \in\left(t_{N}-t_{n+1}, t_{N}-t_{n}\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

abstract:
A numerical scheme for approximating the nonlinear filtering density is
introduced and its convergence rate is established, theoretically under a
parabolic H\"ormander condition, and empirically in two numerical examples. For
the prediction step, between the noisy and partial measurements at discrete
times, the scheme approximates the Fokker--Planck equation with a deep
splitting scheme, combined with an exact update through Bayes' formula. This
results in a classical prediction-update filtering algorithm that operates
online for new observation sequences post-training. The algorithm employs a
sampling-based Feynman--Kac approach, designed to mitigate the curse of
dimensionality. The convergence proof relies on stochastic integration by parts
from the Malliavin calculus. As a corollary we obtain the convergence rate for
the approximation of the Fokker--Planck equation alone, disconnected from the
filtering problem.
